list.description: Avalon Project [archive] (Yale Law School): Explicitly protected slavery in Article I, Section 9.

list.description: National Park Service [archive]; American Battlefield Trust [archive] timelines.

list.title: Jefferson Davis speeches
list.description: Rice University archive [archive]: Confederate president's papers including 1858 Senate speech calling slavery "a moral, a social, and a political blessing."

list.title: 1860 U.S. Census
list.description: Census Bureau: Enslaved population data showing nearly 4 million people held in bondage.

list.title: Texas v. White
list.description: Supreme Court ruling [archive] that secession was unconstitutional: "The Constitution... looks to an indestructible Union composed of indestructible States."

list.title: Wilmington Coup
list.description: History.com: Armed white supremacists overthrew Wilmington's elected biracial government, the only successful coup d'état in American history.

list.title: Plessy v. Ferguson
list.description: Oyez: Supreme Court upheld "separate but equal" doctrine, legalizing segregation for 58 years.

list.title: Dixiecrat Platform
list.description: States' Rights Democratic Party platform [archive]: "We stand for the segregation of the races." The first major break in the Democratic Solid South.

list.title: Brown v. Board of Education
list.description: Oyez: Supreme Court unanimously ruled segregated schools unconstitutional, overturning Plessy.

list.title: Civil Rights Act of 1964
list.description: Senate vote record [archive]: Landmark legislation outlawing discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin.

list.title: Voting Rights Act of 1965
list.description: National Archives [archive]: Prohibited racial discrimination in voting, enabling federal oversight of elections.

list.title: Kevin Phillips interview
list.description: New York Times: Nixon strategist explains the plan to win the South by appealing to white racial resentment.

list.title: Haldeman Diaries
list.description: Nixon Chief of Staff diary [archive]: Documenting Nixon's explicit racial strategy discussions.

list.title: Lee Atwater interview
list.description: The Nation [archive]: GOP strategist explains how racial appeals became "abstract" through coded language.

list.title: Ken Mehlman RNC apology
list.description: NPR [archive]: RNC Chairman apologizes to NAACP: "Some Republicans... trying to benefit politically from racial polarization... we were wrong."

list.title: Shelby County v. Holder
list.description: Oyez [archive]: Supreme Court gutted Voting Rights Act preclearance requirements, enabling new voting restrictions.

list.title: NC NAACP v. McCrory
list.description: 4th Circuit ruling [archive]: Struck down NC voting restrictions that targeted Black voters "with almost surgical precision."

list.title: State voting restrictions
list.description: Virginia; Georgia SB 202; Texas SB 1; Florida SB 7050; North Carolina S747.

list.title: Felony disenfranchisement
list.description: Sentencing Project [archive]: Research on voting rights denied to citizens with felony convictions.

list.title: 2024 election results
list.description: Associated Press state results; 270toWin national map; supplemental cross-check via state election boards.

list.title: Brennan Center voting trackers
list.description: Brennan Center for Justice [archive]: 2024 Review, 2025 Update.

list.title: Party platforms archive
list.description: UCSB American Presidency Project [archive]: Complete collection of party platforms.

list.title: Southern Strategy scholarship
list.description: Encyclopedia Britannica [archive]; Organization of American Historians [archive] primary source collection.

list.title: Historical scholarship
list.description: James McPherson, Battle Cry of Freedom (Pulitzer Prize); Edward Baptist, The Half Has Never Been Told; AHA "16 Months to Sumter" [archive].

list.title: Memphis Massacre 1866
list.description: National Park Service: White mobs murdered 46 Black people over 3 days. Congressional investigation led to the 14th Amendment.

list.title: New Orleans Massacre 1866
list.description: National Park Service: Police and white mobs attacked a constitutional convention debating Black voting rights, killing 34-50. General Sheridan called it 'an absolute massacre.'

list.title: Colfax Massacre 1873
list.description: National Park Service: Easter Sunday massacre where 60-150 Black militia members were executed after surrendering. Supreme Court ruling in U.S. v. Cruikshank (1876) gutted federal civil rights enforcement.

list.title: Hamburg Massacre 1876
list.description: SC Encyclopedia: On America's centennial, Red Shirts militia executed Black militia members after surrender. Massacre leader Matthew Butler was elected U.S. Senator.

list.title: Wilmington Coup 1898
list.description: NC Dept. of Natural and Cultural Resources: The only successful coup d'état in American history. White supremacists overthrew an elected biracial government and murdered 60-300 Black citizens. Textbooks falsely called it a 'race riot' until the 2006 state commission report corrected the record; curriculum wasn't updated until 2011.

list.title: Tulsa Race Massacre 1921
list.description: Tulsa Historical Society: White mobs destroyed 'Black Wall Street,' killing 100-300+ and leaving 10,000 homeless. The massacre was hidden from textbooks for decades.

list.title: Thaddeus Stevens speeches
list.description: Teaching American History: Radical Republican leader's demand for Confederate land confiscation and treason trials. 'Strip a proud nobility of their bloated estates.'

list.title: Stevens epitaph
list.description: Thaddeus Stevens Society [NPS archive]: Stevens chose burial in a Black cemetery to 'illustrate in my death the principles which I advocated through a long life: Equality of Man before his Creator.' (Note: Original NPS page removed in 2025 under EO 'Restoring Truth and Sanity to American History.' Dead link: nps.gov/thst/learn/historyculture/stevens-epitaph.htm)

list.title: Andrew Johnson quotes
list.description: American Presidency Project: Johnson's Third Annual Message defending his obstruction of Reconstruction; White House biography.

list.title: Lost Cause origins
list.description: Edward Pollard's The Lost Cause (1866) named the mythology; Southern Historical Society Papers institutionalized it; UDC placed monuments and controlled textbooks.

list.title: U.S. v. Cruikshank
list.description: Cornell Law: Supreme Court ruled the 14th Amendment only applied to state action, not private violence. Effectively legalized Klan terrorism.

list.title: Sherman's Special Field Order No. 15
list.description: National Archives: '40 acres and a mule' order that granted 400,000 acres to freed people. Reversed by Andrew Johnson, who returned land to former slaveholders.

list.title: Confederate monument timing
list.description: Southern Poverty Law Center [archive]: Most monuments erected during Jim Crow (1890s-1920s) and Civil Rights era (1950s-1960s), not memorials, but intimidation.

list.title: The Southern Manifesto
list.description: Civil Rights Movement Archive (PDF) [archive]: 101 Southern congressmen signed a declaration opposing Brown v. Board. Track where each signatory's seat ended up—nearly all Republican.

list.title: Wallace Inaugural Address
list.description: Alabama Archives: George Wallace's 'segregation now, segregation tomorrow, segregation forever' speech. He won 5 Southern states in 1968; his voters became Republicans.

list.title: Reagan Neshoba County Speech
list.description: Neshoba Democrat: Reagan launched his general election campaign 7 miles from where civil rights workers were murdered, declaring 'I believe in states' rights.'

list.title: Mississippi Black Codes
list.description: BlackPast: Laws passed immediately after the Civil War to re-enslave Black people in all but name. Shows what happened when the South was left to 'reconstruct' itself.

list.title: Mississippi Convention 1890
list.description: Facing History: Convention president declared 'We came here to exclude the negro.' Jim Crow's purpose stated explicitly.

list.title: Crittenden Compromise
list.description: Yale Avalon (Archive): The South rejected this compromise because it didn't provide ENOUGH protection for slavery. Proves it was never about 'states' rights.'

list.title: Justice Harlan's Plessy Dissent
list.description: Cornell Law: 'Our Constitution is color-blind.' The lone dissenter in Plessy v. Ferguson—it took 58 years for the Court to catch up.

list.title: Frederick Douglass July 4th Speech
list.description: Teaching American History: 'What, to the American slave, is your 4th of July?' The most powerful indictment of American slavery.

list.title: Lincoln's First Inaugural
list.description: Yale Avalon: Lincoln promised NOT to interfere with slavery—and the South attacked Fort Sumter anyway. They weren't defending themselves.

list.title: LBJ 'We Shall Overcome' Speech
list.description: Miller Center: A Southern president embracing the civil rights anthem one week after Bloody Sunday. Democrats chose civil rights over the Solid South.

list.title: Hiram Revels Senate Speech
list.description: Senate Archives: First Black Senator's speech on reconciliation. No Black Southerner would serve in Congress again until 1973.

list.title: 13th Amendment
list.description: National Archives: Abolished slavery. Ratified December 6, 1865.

list.title: 14th Amendment
list.description: National Archives: Granted citizenship and equal protection. Ratified July 9, 1868.

list.title: 15th Amendment
list.description: National Archives: Prohibited racial discrimination in voting. Ratified February 3, 1870. Effectively nullified by Jim Crow until the Voting Rights Act.

list.title: Ida B. Wells - Southern Horrors
list.description: Project Gutenberg: Ida B. Wells' documentation of lynching. Primary source evidence of racial terrorism during Jim Crow.

eras.name: Secession Era
eras.description: The Civil War and the documents that started it

gallery.title: Mississippi Declaration (1861)
gallery.content: "Our position is thoroughly identified with the institution of slavery... a blow at slavery is a blow at commerce and civilization." The document lists threats to slavery as the motivation for leaving the Union.

gallery.title: Stephens Cornerstone (1861)
gallery.content: Alexander Stephens proclaimed that the Confederacy stands on "the great truth that the negro is not equal to the white man; that slavery and subordination to the superior race is his natural condition."

gallery.title: Voting Rights Act (1965)
gallery.content: Section 2 forbids any voting rule that results in discrimination on account of race or color. It empowered federal oversight that reshaped Southern politics and accelerated party realignment.

gallery.title: 1972 Presidential Map
gallery.content: Richard Nixon swept every former Confederate state while George McGovern carried Massachusetts and Washington DC. The map visualizes the completed migration of white Southern voters into the GOP coalition.
